kinematics.text: Why do we need the concept of speed? Where does it come from?
kinematics.hint: Think about what question speed answers. How else could you describe an object's motion?

kinematics.text: What's the difference between speed and velocity? Why does direction matter?
kinematics.hint: Consider two cars traveling at 60 mph - one north, one south. Are they moving the same way?

kinematics.text: Why is acceleration the 'rate of change of velocity'? What does this mean intuitively?
kinematics.hint: Think about what changes when you press the gas pedal or brake pedal in a car.

kinematics.text: If I drop two objects simultaneously from the same height, why do they hit the ground at the same time regardless of mass (ignoring air resistance)?
kinematics.hint: Consider Newton's second law and how gravity affects different masses.

forces-momentum.text: What does it really mean that 'an object in motion stays in motion'? Why doesn't everything around us just keep moving forever?
forces-momentum.hint: Consider what forces act on everyday objects like a rolling ball or a moving car.

forces-momentum.text: If F=ma, why does a heavy box feel harder to push than a light box?
forces-momentum.hint: To achieve the same acceleration, what must change in the equation?

forces-momentum.text: When you push on a wall, the wall pushes back with equal force (Newton's 3rd law). So why don't you move?
forces-momentum.hint: Consider what other forces are acting on you, like friction with the ground.

forces-momentum.text: Why can a rocket work in space where there's nothing to 'push against'?
forces-momentum.hint: Think about action-reaction pairs. What is the rocket pushing?

work-energy-power.text: What IS energy? Why is it useful to have this concept?
work-energy-power.hint: Think about what's conserved when a ball bounces, when you climb stairs, or when a car brakes.

work-energy-power.text: Why do we say energy is 'conserved' when a bouncing ball clearly loses energy and stops bouncing?
work-energy-power.hint: Where does the energy go? Is it destroyed or transformed?

work-energy-power.text: How can potential energy exist 'in' an object? Is it really stored there?
work-energy-power.hint: Consider the relationship between the object and Earth. Could potential energy exist for a single object alone in space?

electric-magnetic-fields.text: What IS an electric field? Is it real or just a mathematical tool?
electric-magnetic-fields.hint: Think about the space around a charge. How does another charge 'know' to experience a force?

electric-magnetic-fields.text: Why do we use the concept of 'field' at all? Why not just talk about forces between charges?
electric-magnetic-fields.hint: Consider situations with many charges, or when we don't know all the charges present.

electric-magnetic-fields.text: What does it mean that electric field points 'away from' positive charges and 'toward' negative charges?
electric-magnetic-fields.hint: Think about what would happen to a positive test charge placed in the field.
